section.title: Constant Acceleration Motion
section.p: The one-dimensional kinematics for constant acceleration motion plays an important practical role. Typically, we are interested in a motion between two instants in time, which we call the initial and final instants. We use subscripts i and f to denote quantities at these instants. The following diagram illustrates the setup.

figure.caption: Set up for constant acceleration motion along the x axis with a_x same throughout the interval. The time interval of interest is \Delta t = t_f - t_i. The initial and final positions are x_i and x_f respectively, with displacement \Delta x = x_f - x_i. The initial and final velocities are v_{i,x} and v_{f,x} resectively, with change \Delta v_x = v_{f,x} - v_{i,x} .

section.p: We denote the interval by \Delta t = t_f - t_i , the change in position by \Delta x = x_f-x_i , and change in velocity by \Delta v_x = v_{f,x} - v_{i,x} .

They obey the following relations.
\amp \Delta v_x = a_x \Delta t. \amp \Delta x = v_{av,x} \Delta t,
where
v_{av,x} = \dfrac{v_{i,x} + v_{f,x}}{2}.
It is possible to eliminate \Delta t from these equations to obtain
v_{f,x}^2 = v_{i,x}^2 + 2 a_x \left( \Delta x \right)^2,
which we will refer to as the no-t-equation . It is also possible to eliminate v_{f,x} to obtain another useful equation
\Delta x = v_{i,x} \Delta t + \dfrac{1}{2}a_x\left(\Delta t \right)^2,
which we will refer to as the no-v_f-equation.

Sign conventions. We use a sign convention to follow the directions of velocity and acceleration. The source of these sign conventions will become clear after you learn vectors. The following diagrams clarify the sign assignments of velocity and acceleration.

p.p: The velocity v_x is positive if object is moving in the direction of positive axis and negative if in the opposite direction.
Acceleration a_x is positive in two situations: if either v_x is positive and speeding up OR v_x is negative and slowing down.
Acceleration a_x is negative in two situations: if either v_x is negative and speeding up OR v_x is positive and slowing down.

exercise.title: Predicting the Final Velocity in a Constant Acceleration Motion

statement.p: A skier is coming down a steep slope with a constant acceleration a = 3.0\text{ m/s}^2. If the speed of the skier at the top of the hill was 0 , what is his speed when he has skied a distance of 40 \text{ m} down the hill? Take the positive x axis to point down the hill.

hint.p: Since we don't need \Delta t the no-t-equation can be useful

solution.p:
For the sake of brevity, we will drop the coordinate subscript x from the symbols. Here taking the x axis down the hill makes all the motion along the x axis. From the problem statement, we can get the following.
a = 3.0\text{ m/s}^2,\ \ \Delta x = 40 \text{ m},\ \ v_i = 0,\ \ v_f = ?
The no-t-equation is perfect for this and gives
v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2 a (\Delta x)^2 = 0 + 2 \times 3 \times 40^2 = 9600.
Taking square root of both sides gives two values
v_f = \pm 98\text{ m/s}.
Since the velocity we want to in the direction of the positive x axis, we want the positive root.
v_f = + 98\text{ m/s}.
We want the speed, which is the absolute value of this velocity.

statement.p: A car can accelerate from zero velocity to 30 m/s in 2.5 seconds.
(a) What is the acceleration of the car?
(b) What is the average velocity of the car when it accelerating from zero velocity to 30 m/s?
(c) How far does the car travel during the 2.5 s?

hint.p: Think the motion on x axis and try using the constant acceleration equations.

solution.p:
(a) From the change in velocity we find
a = \dfrac{v_f - v_i}{t} = \dfrac{30 \text{ m/s} - 0}{2.5\text{ s}} = 12 \text{ m/s}^2.

(b) Since acceleration is constant, average velocity will be average of initial and final velocities.
v_{av} = \dfrac{v_f + v_i}{2} = \dfrac{30 \text{ m/s} + 0}{2} = 15 \text{ m/s}.

(c) From average velocity and duration, we get the displacement to be
x_f - x_i = v_{av} t = 15 \text{ m/s} \times 2.5 \text{ s} = 37.5 \text{ m}.

exercise.title: Stopping Distance in a Constant Deceleration Situation

statement.p: The maximum deceleration of a particular car is 30.0 \text{ m/s}^2. The car is moving at a steady pace of 40.0 \text{m/s} on a straight road. The driver notices a deer on the road and applies the maximum brake right away. How far the deer must be if the car must stop before it hits the deer?

hint.p: Think the motion on x axis and try using the constant acceleration equations.

solution.p:
Here, we are given that acceleration is in the opposite direction of initial velocity. So, if the initial veloccity v_x is positive, the acceleration a_xwill be negative. For brevity, I will drop x from the symbols. We have
v_i = 40.0 \text{ m/s}, \ \ v_f = 0, \ \ a = - 30.0 \text{ m/s}^2,
and we are to find \Delta x, which is another way to write x_f-x_i. Using the no t equation we get (I will omit units in the calculations.)
v_f^2 - v_i^2 = 2 a \Delta x \rightarrow 0 - 40^2 = 2 \times 30 \times \Delta x
Therefore,
\Delta x = 26.7 \text{ m}.

statement.p: Starting from rest a box slides down an incline at a constant acceleration of 2\text{ m/s}^2 pointed down the incline (not vertically down).
(a) Find the speed of the box at t = 1.5 sec.
(b) Find the average velocity of the box between t = 0 and t =1.5 sec.
(c) Determine the distance traveled on the incline in 1.5 sec.
(d) Verify that the displacement during the 1.5 sec interval from t = 0 to t =1.5 sec is equal to the product of the average velocity for the interval and the time interval.

hint.p: Using +x axis down the incline will be helpful.

solution.p:
Let us point +x axis down the incline. This will give
a_x = + 2\text{ m/s}^2,\ \ v_{ix} = 0,\ \ \Delta t = 1.5\text{ sec}\equiv t.

(a) Therefore,
v_{fx} = v_{ix} + a_x t = 0 + 2\times 1.5 = 3.0\text{ m/s}.
This gives final speed equal to 3.0\text{ m/s}.

(b) For constant acceleration, average velocity is just the average of initial and final velocities.
v_\text{av,x} = \dfrac{v_{ix} + v_{fx}}{2} = 1.5\text{ m/s}.

(c) The displacement from initial velocity and accl will be
\Delta x = v_{ix} t + \dfrac{1}{2}a t^2 = 0 + \dfrac{1}{2}\times 2\times 1.5^2 = 2.25\text{ m}.

(d) Using average velocity and duration we verify
\Delta x = v_\text{av,x}\, t= 1.5\times 1.5 = 2.25\text{ m}.

exercise.title: Deceleration of a Hockey Puck While Moving up an Incline

statement.p: A hockey puck is hit up an incline. The puck slows down at a constant acceleration of magnitude 5\text{ m/s}^2 and stops after 1.2 sec.
(a) Find the initial velocity, i.e. the velocity of the puck immediately after leaving the stick.
(b) How far up the incline does the puck go before coming to rest?
(c) What are the directions of velocity and acceleration at t = 0.5\text{ sec}?
(d) Find the position of the puck at t = 0.5\text{ sec}.

hint.p: (a) and (b) have different time interval than (c) and (d).

solution.p:
Let +x axis be pointed up the incline. This makes
a_x = - 5.0\text{ m/s}^2,\ \ \Delta t = 1.2\text{ sec}\equiv t,\ \ v_{fx} = 0.

(a) From v_f = v_i + a t we get
v_{ix} = v_{f,x} - a t = 0-(-5)\times 1.2 = 6.0\text{ m/s}.

(b) From \Delta x = v_{ix} + \dfrac{1}{2}at^2, we get
\Delta x = 6\times 1.2 + \dfrac{1}{2}\times (-5)\times 1.2^2 = 3.6\text{ m}.

(c) Now, t=0.5\text{ s} and v_{fx}\ne 0. We can use v_{ix} found above to find v_{fx}.
v_{fx} = v_{ix} + a_x t = 6.0 + (-5)\times 0.5 = 3.5\text{ m/s}.

(d) The displacement
\Delta x \amp = \dfrac{v_{ix} + v_{fx}}{2}\, \Delta t \amp = \dfrac{6 + 3.5}{2}\times 0.5 = 2.375\text{ m}.

statement.p: A skater after an initial push glides with a constant deceleration. He comes to a stop after reaching 120 m in 25\text{ sec}.
(a) Find his initial speed.
(b) Find the deceleration.
(c) How much distance did he cover in the first 12.5 sec?
(d) How much distance did he cover in the last 12.5 sec?

hint.p: Use +x axis in the direction of motion.

solution.p:
(a) With +x axis in the direction of motion, we have
\Delta x = 120 \text{ m},\ \ v_{fx} = 0,\ \ \Delta t = 25\text{ s}\equiv t.
Using \Delta x = v_{\text{av},x}\, \Delta t and v_{\text{av},x} = (v_{ix}+v_{fx})/2, we get
120\text{ m} = \dfrac{v_{ix} + 0 }{2} \times 25\text{ s}.
Therefore,
v_{ix} = 9.6\text{ m/s}.

(b)
a_x = \dfrac{v_{fx} - v_{ix}}{\Delta t }= \dfrac{ 0 - 9.6 }{25} = - 0.384\text{ m/s}^2.

(c) Now, we have
v_{ix} = 9.6\text{ m/s},\ \ a_x = - 0.384\text{ m/s}^2,\ \ \Delta t = 12.5\text{ s}\equiv t.
Therefore
\Delta x \amp = v_{ix} t + \dfrac{1}{2}a_x t^2 \amp = 9.6 \times 12.5 + \dfrac{1}{2} \times (-0.384) \times 12.5^2 = 90\text{ m}.

(d)
\Delta x = 120\text{ m} - 90\text{ m} = 30\text{ m}.

exercise.title: Constant Acceleration on an Inclined Plane

statement.p: A truck is parked on an inclined slippery road. Suddenly, the brake fails and the truck starts to slide down the incline. You notice that starting from rest, the truck has picked up a speed of 20.0 m/s over a period of 30.0 seconds. (a) Assuming constant acceleration, how far has the truck moved in this time? (b) What is the acceleration of the truck?

hint.p: Assume x axis down the incline.

answer.p: (a) 300.0 m, (b) 0.67 \text{ m/s}^2 pointed down the incline.

solution.p: (a) Since we have a constant acceleration situation, it is easy to get average velocity from the initial and final velocities. Here, the initial velocity v_i = 0 since the truck was not moving initially, and the final velocity v_f = 20.0 m/s. v_{av} = \dfrac{0 + 20.0}{2} = 10.0 \text{ m/s}. Therefore, the distance moved in t = 30.0 sec: \Delta x = v_{av} t = 10.0 \text{ m/s} \times 30.0 \text{ s} = 300.0 \text{ m}.

(b) To get a , we just use the velocities and time given. a = \dfrac{v_f - v_i }{t} = \dfrac{2}{3} \text{ m/s}^2. From the description, it is clear that truck's speed is picking up. Hence, the direction of the acceleration is same as the direction in which the truck is moving, which is down the inclined road.

exercise.title: Modeling a Varying Acceleration by Average Constant Acceleration

statement.p: A cheeta's acceleration varies during its motion over a wide range. An example is given in below. Even though, the real-life situation is complicated, we can get a lot of physics by modeling the motion as if the motion was a constant acceleration motion, by replacing the varying acceleration by an average acceleration value. You would, of course not get the exact values, but your answer will be in the right ball park.

Suppose, the average acceleration of a cheetah between t=0 and t = 30\text{ sec} is 2.2\text{ m/s}^2. If cheetah started out at rest, what will be (a) the distance traveled and (b) speed at t = 30\text{ sec}?

hint.p: For both (a) and (b) use constant acceleration equations.

solution.p:
(a) Since \Delta t and v_i are given to us, the following equation will give the displacement.
\Delta x = v_{i,x}\Delta t + \dfrac{1}{2} a_{\text{av},x} (\Delta t)^2.
With the numerical values given, we get
\Delta x = 0 + \dfrac{1}{2} \times 2.2\times 30^2 = 990\text{ m}.

(b) The velocity at the final instant can be obtained by
v_{f,x} = v_{i,x} + a_{\text{av},x}\, \Delta t = 2.2\times 30 = 66\text{ m/s}.
